item.title: David Cameron Expected to Allow Cabinet to Pick Sides on E.U. Exit
item.description: Requiring a unified position on the issue could bring embarrassing resignations for the British prime minister as well as further splits in the Conservative Party.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER and STEPHEN CASTLE
item.media:description: Prime Minister David Cameron of Britain at a news conference after a European Union summit meeting in Brussels last month.

item.title: Kuwait Recalls Its Envoy in Iran Amid Feud With Saudi Arabia
item.description: The decision came a day after Bahrain and Sudan cut diplomatic ties with Iran, and the United Arab Emirates downgraded relations with Iran.
item.dc:creator: SEWELL CHAN

item.title: Warri Journal: Nigeria Goes to the Mall
item.description: With its surging middle class, Africa’s most populous nation is embracing the places, and culture, that are sagging in America.
item.dc:creator: NORIMITSU ONISHI
item.media:credit: Glenna Gordon for The New York Times
item.media:description: The checkout at Shoprite, Africa’s biggest food retailer, in a new shopping center in Warri, a fast-growing city in Nigeria’s oil-producing region.

item.title: Take a Number: In a First, Element Will Be Named by Researchers in Japan
item.description: Element 113 is credited to scientists from the Riken institute in Japan, who will bestow an official name more than 12 years after they began their efforts.
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
International Union of Pure and Applied Physics
International Union of Pure and Applied Chemistry
item.dc:creator: NICHOLAS ST. FLEUR
item.media:description: Kosuke Morita of the Riken institute in Japan led the team with the strongest claim to having discovered element 113 on the periodic table.

item.title: News Analysis: U.S. Struggles to Explain Alliance With Saudis
item.description: The Obama administration could not bring itself to condemn the execution of a dissident cleric who challenged the royal family, for fear of undermining the Saudi leadership it desperately needs in fighting ISIS.
item.dc:creator: DAVID E. SANGER
item.media:description: King Salman of Saudi Arabia last month in Riyadh. The American perception that the Saudis are critical to stability in the region continues to hold together an increasingly fractious marriage between the two countries.

item.title: World Briefing: Central African Republic: A Call by Candidates to Halt Vote Count
item.description: The tallying of the national elections must stop, about two-thirds of the 30 Central African Republic presidential candidates said Monday, alleging fraud.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Haiti: Panel Says Election Irregularities Were Due to Incompetence, Not Fraud
item.description: A commission that evaluated Haiti’s presidential election said that most of the irregularities it found in first-round voting were the result of widespread ineptitude by poll workers.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Death Sentences Surge, Even as More Countries Drop Capital Punishment
item.description: Amnesty International found a 28 percent increase in the number of people sentenced to death in 2014, as some countries resumed capital punishment after suspending it for years.
item.dc:creator: SOMINI SENGUPTA
item.media:description: This man's life was spared at the last minute in Iran in 2014. One of the world’s leading executioners, Iran executed at least 289 people that year, according to Amnesty International.

item.title: Shiite Cleric Gained in Status as a Rivalry Deepened
item.description: The rise to prominence of Sheikh Nimr al-Nimr, who was scarcely known outside of Saudi Arabia before his arrest in 2012, corresponds closely with the intensification of the rivalry between Shiite Iran and Sunni Saudi Arabia.
item.dc:creator: BEN HUBBARD
item.media:description: Shiite clerics in Karbala, Iraq, stood on a poster of King Salman of Saudi Arabia during a demonstration on Monday.

item.title: World Briefing: Libya: Islamic State Attacks Oil Port
item.description: Islamic State militants attempted to capture an oil port along Libya’s coast, in fighting that left at least seven people dead and set fire to a storage tank of crude oil.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: SULIMAN ALI ZWAY

item.title: World Briefing: France: Charlie Hebdo Plans Edition to Mark Anniversary of Massacre
item.description: Seventeen people died at Charlie Hebdo in 2014 and in other attacks in the Paris area in the days that followed.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Streets, if Not the Air, Clear Out as Delhi Tests Car Restrictions
item.description: The experiment has riled many of the Indian capital’s elite even as its ability to reduce pollution remains unclear, with air quality still at “hazardous” levels Monday.
item.dc:creator: NIDA NAJAR
item.media:description: Delhi on a smog-enveloped Monday morning, the fourth day of a two-week experiment to limit cars on roads in the region to fight pollution.

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Saudi Arabia’s Dangerous Sectarian Game
item.description: The Saudi royals think that stoking hatred of Shiites will keep them in power.
item.dc:creator: TOBY CRAIG JONES
item.media:description: Demonstrators in Iran on Monday protested the executions in Saudi Arabia.

item.title: Iran, Emerging From Sanctions, Faces Crisis After Saudi Arabia Embassy Attack
item.description: Some Iranians are wondering whether Saudi Arabia has again gained the upper hand in a new diplomatic crisis.
item.dc:creator: THOMAS ERDBRINK
item.media:description: Shiite Muslims in New Delhi were held back by security forces Monday as they protested Saudi Arabia's execution of a dissident cleric, Sheikh Nimr al-Nimr.

item.title: Q&A: How Do Sunni and Shia Islam Differ?
item.description: Here is a primer on the differences between the two branches of Islam.
item.dc:creator: JOHN HARNEY
item.media:description: Sunnis and Shiites praying together on Sunday in Beirut, Lebanon, in protest of the execution of Sheikh Nimr al-Nimr.

item.title: Hezbollah Attacks Israeli Military Vehicles
item.description: The militant group said the assault in a disputed border area was a response to Israel’s killing of Samir Kuntar, a Hezbollah operative, last month.
item.dc:creator: ANNE BARNARD

item.title: Bombings Near Kabul Airport Add to String of Attacks Around Afghan Capital
item.description: In the more powerful of the Monday attacks, a truck of explosives was rammed into the wall of a compound for foreign and Afghan civilian contractors, killing one and injuring more than 20.
item.dc:creator: JAWAD SUKHANYAR and MUJIB MASHAL
item.media:description: Afghans carried a wounded man after a suicide attack near Kabul's international airport on Monday.

item.title: European Sympathies Lean Toward Iran in Conflict With Saudi Arabia
item.description: Iran has long been a pariah, but Saudi Arabia’s embrace of the death penalty and its support of extremist Sunni ideology has hardened some Western attitudes.
item.dc:creator: SEWELL CHAN

item.title: Sinosphere: Leveling Criticism at China’s Elite, Some Borrow Words From the Past
item.description: The term “Zhao family,” from a novella by Lu Xun, has resurfaced as a disparaging stand-in for China’s rich and politically connected.
item.dc:creator: KIKI ZHAO
item.media:description: A phrase from a story by Lu Xun, one of China’s most revered writers of the early 20th century, has made its way into online commentaries as a disparaging reference to the country’s rich and powerful.

item.title: Migrant Who Walked Channel Tunnel Is Granted Asylum in Britain
item.description: Abdul Rahman Haroun, the Sudanese man who walked from France to England, might still face charges for obstructing a railway engine.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER
